title: How to Start a Tow Truck Business
description: Find out how to start a tow truck business so you can be part of a service that is always needed, no matter how bad the economy is doing.

The scope of a towing business varies but commonly includes services like vehicle recovery, jump starts, tire changes, and hauling vehicles for impoundment or to a repair shop. Depending on the scale, some companies may offer additional services like long-distance towing, heavy-duty towing for larger vehicles, or roadside assistance.

Why Start a Towing Business?

Starting a tow truck business can be a significant undertaking, but it can offer numerous advantages for those willing to put in the effort. Here are some reasons why you might consider embarking on this venture:

  1. High Demand in Certain Areas:
    • Urban and suburban areas with high vehicle density often require regular towing services due to accidents, illegal parking, or vehicle breakdowns.
    • Tourist locations, especially those with limited parking or challenging terrains, might see frequent need for towing services.
  2. Potential for High Revenue:
    • The initial investment might be substantial, but with a well-planned business model, the potential for a substantial return on investment exists.
    • Towing services often come with immediate payments, reducing the risk of outstanding debts.
  3. Diverse Service Offerings:
    • Beyond standard towing, businesses can offer related services like jump-starts, tire changes, lock-out services, or even roadside assistance packages.
  4. Build Strong Community Relations:
    • Working closely with local law enforcement, businesses, and community members can foster positive relationships and build a good reputation.
    • Partnerships or contracts with local businesses or municipalities can provide consistent work.
  5. Opportunity for Expansion:
    • As your business develops, you may have the opportunity to branch out into additional related fields, such as vehicle storage, salvage operations, or auto repair services.
  6. Independence and Autonomy:
    • Running a tow truck business provides the opportunity to be your own boss, make independent decisions, and influence the company’s direction and growth.
    • Tow truck driving is among the top outdoor business ideas for those who enjoy spending time outside a traditional office.
  7. Challenging and Rewarding Work:
    • Every day can bring new challenges, which can be fulfilling for those who enjoy problem-solving and helping others in distress.

However, there are also challenges to consider:

  • Long Hours: Towing services may be needed at any hour, day or night. Consequently, business owners should be ready to work non-traditional and extended hours.
  • Heavy Initial Investment: Purchasing towing vehicles and related equipment can be expensive. Securing funding or loans might be necessary.
  • Understanding Local Laws and Regulations: Towing businesses must adhere to strict regulations regarding where vehicles can be towed and the fees that can be charged. Familiarizing yourself with these rules is essential to prevent any legal complications.
  • Risk of Damage: Handling other people’s vehicles always carries the risk of damage. Proper training, small business insurance, and safety protocols are essential.

In conclusion, while there are challenges associated with starting a tow truck business, the potential rewards can be significant for those who are passionate, prepared, and well-informed.

The Automobile Towing Industry Today

The tow truck industry in the United States is robust, especially in urban and densely populated regions. The Bureau of Labor Statistics reports that employment in the towing sector is projected to grow at an average rate. This stability is driven by several factors, including the rising number of vehicles and legal regulations mandating towing services.

What Do Tow Truck Companies Do?

A tow truck company can earn extra money by adding additional services.

Vehicle Towing

Of course, the basic service provided by a towing company is towing a vehicle. Depending on the size of the disabled vehicle, the tow truck companies respond with various types of equipment.

Roadside Assistance

Some tow companies can save the customer the cost of a tow by providing basic repair, such as changing a tire or fixing a leak (antifreeze, power steering, etc.).

Vehicle Storage

Many times, when a vehicle breaks down, it is towed to a repair shop. But if a vehicle is severely damaged in an accident, it may be towed to a storage facility.

This can be a lucrative service provided by a towing company. Vehicle storage rates are generally a minimum of $40 per day.

Contractual Towing for Institutions

An educational institution may want to lock in a reliable towing service. A towing service could be needed for any of the institution’s vehicles, such as vans transporting sports teams or clubs, vehicles used by a campus security department, or vehicles used for road upkeep (plow trucks).

Contractual Towing for Law Enforcement

It’s imperative that vehicles involved in an accident or vehicles being seized from an impaired driver are removed from the site as quickly as possible. Many law enforcement entities, from small towns to state police, want to have a reliable towing company on contract, available 24/7.

Contractual Towing for RePo Companies

This is also a lucrative add-on to a towing business. However, it can involve additional focus on maintaining personal safety, such as asking law enforcement to be on the scene providing support.

The Role of Tow Truck Drivers

A tow truck driver is responsible for responding to service calls, safely securing vehicles, towing them to the designated location, and conducting minor roadside repairs if needed. They must also maintain their equipment, comply with safety regulations, and manage basic customer service interactions.

Key Steps to Start Your Own Towing Business

You can get started fairly cheaply with a used tow truck. However, several other steps are required as you learn how to start a business in this exciting industry.

Conduct Market Research on Towing Services

Find out how many tow services are operating in the area and also analyze the scope of their services. There may be a niche that isn’t being serviced.

Crafting Your Tow Truck Business Plan

Start with the organization of your business. Will you form a Limited Liability Company (LLC), partnership or corporation? Who will own the company? What are the long-range plans for growing the business?

Although writing a business plan may not appear to be at the top of your list of essential tasks, it is crucial. When you seek financing to grow your operations, lenders will require your business plan. Keep this requirement in mind as you develop your plan.

Business Start-Up Costs for Towing Companies

The cost of a tow truck can vary widely based on its type and capabilities. A basic used tow truck can start around $10,000-$15,000, while new models can range from $50,000 for a light-duty truck to upwards of $200,000 for a heavy-duty tow truck designed to handle large vehicles. These figures don’t include additional equipment or customization.

Registering Your Tow Truck Business and Legal Requirements

Legal requirements vary by jurisdiction but typically include business licenses, special towing permits, liability insurance, and compliance with local, state, and federal regulations regarding transportation and safety. Some areas require tow truck operators to participate in rotations for emergency service towing.

Financing Your Tow Truck Business

Financing options include personal savings, bank loans, or investors. An initial business plan detailing expected costs, revenue, and growth metrics is crucial for securing financial backing. Many business owners start small, perhaps with a single truck, and scale up as revenue increases.

Necessary Licenses and Certifications for Towing Services

Licenses often include a general business license, a commercial driver’s license (CDL) for drivers, and any state-specific towing licenses. Certifications from industry organizations like the Towing and Recovery Association of America (TRAA) can bolster credibility.

Running a Successful Tow Truck Business

Customers have a choice. There is rarely only one tow truck business in an area. To be successful, you need to stay focused on the most important elements of your business:

Quality of Service and Customer Satisfaction

Respond promptly and be courteous. If you’re responding to a disabled motorist, remember that the breakdown is very upsetting to them.

Efficient Operations and Fleet Management

Although a tow truck company may start with one truck, that is not a wise way to continue operations. A successful tow truck company is always able to respond.

Marketing Your Tow Truck Business

You should build a website and social media presence. If you aren’t tech-savvy, hire a professional to set up those things. Network with related businesses in the area, such as auto repair shops.

Building Long-term Client Relationships

If you are lucky enough to have established a contract with a valuable client, like a law enforcement agency or educational institution, be sure to express your gratitude. A simple thank-you note can make a significant impact.

Safety Protocols and Training

Situations are different and can depend on many factors, such as the type of road (dirt or highway), weather, time of day (rush hour), and type of vehicle. The tow truck driver needs to think about the best way to tow the vehicle while remaining personally safe and safely. Proper placement of flares and other safety markers is important. Law enforcement personnel can respond and provide flashing lights that alert other motorists to adjust their speed.

Tools and Equipment Needed To Start a Towing Company

The basic equipment includes a tow truck, which may be a flatbed or a dolly tow truck, depending on the services offered. Additional equipment like winches, chains, ramps, and safety lights are also necessary. Some companies invest in specialized trucks for heavy-duty towing.

Tow Vehicles and Types

The primary types of tow trucks include flatbed trucks, which use a hydraulic tilting bed to carry vehicles; hook and chain trucks, which are generally used for junk or wrecked cars; wheel-lift trucks, which lift one set of the vehicle’s wheels off the ground; and integrated trucks, which are specialized for heavy-duty applications.

Each type is suited for different kinds of towing jobs.

GPS and Communication Tools for Tow Trucks

It’s important to be able to find the vehicle that needs to be towed. A customer may be traveling through an area and not able to provide an exact location. It’s important to be able to communicate by phone to pinpoint where the vehicle is located.

Emergency Roadside Tools

Tow trucks should carry basic emergency tools such as jumper cables, tire inflators, basic tool kits, road flares or LED warning lights, and first aid kits.

These tools enable the driver to offer a range of services beyond just towing and are essential for addressing minor roadside emergencies.

Marketing and Growing Your Tow Truck Business

Digital Marketing Strategies for Tow Truck Businesses

So what is marketing for a tow truck business, anyway? It’s helpful to develop an App for your towing business. That way, there’s an easy portal for people to use to reach you.

Use online marketing and keep postings coming on a FB page. Show images of your recent work.

Networking with Auto Repair Shops

Often, a vehicle will need to be towed to a repair shop. Depending on the type and age of the vehicle, it may have to go to a specific shop.

For example, if a new vehicle is under warranty, a dealership usually must do repair work. Certain car models may require special diagnostic equipment.

Network with many auto repair shops. When you tow a vehicle there, you are bringing them business.

Customer Retention and Loyalty Programs

These types of programs are important for your contractual customers. Keep the contracts being renewed by including customer retention and loyalty programs. Offer incentives for leads to new customers and offer discounts for certain types or numbers of tow services provided.

FAQs: How to Start a Tow Truck Business

How profitable is a tow truck business?

: Income for towing businesses can fluctuate based on location, services offered, and competition. According to various industry reports, smaller, single-truck operations might earn between $50,000 and $100,000 in revenue per year, while larger companies can pull in well over $500,000 to even millions annually.

Profit margins often range from 10% to 20% but can vary based on operating costs.

What qualifications do tow truck drivers need?

Tow truck drivers generally must have a high school diploma or equivalent, a clean driving record, and a Commercial Driver’s License (CDL) in many cases.

Some states require additional certification or training in towing procedures and safety protocols. Physical strength and the ability to work in varied weather conditions are also essential.

What is the average Tow Truck Cost?

A basic used tow truck will cost between $10,000 and $15,000. A tow truck capable of towing heavy vehicles can cost as much as $200,000.
